bibl.title: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, November 17, 1922

div1.p: Rose reports on American yellow fever deaths in Ceara, Brazil. He also mentions incidents of yellow fever in Africa.

November 17, 1922
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
In my letter to you of November 11 I enclosed copy of a
letter to Doctor White concerning yellow fever in Fortaleza, Ceara,
Brazil. The Mr. Neff referred to in that letter has since told us
that he has been informed by a friend in Fortaleza that an American
named Mr. Lee Greenleaf died of what was locally diagnosed as yellow
fever in Ceara on October 18. This is the same case as Dr. Hackett re-
ported to us by cable.

Since there are many Americans and other non-immunes now
at work in that region on a great engineering enterprise undertaken
by an American firm for the Brazilian government, the situation
there seems serious. The death of Mr. Greenleaf, according to Doctor
Hackett, makes the fifth, accompanied by symptoms suspiciously like
those of yellow fever, which has been reported among Americans in the
last few months. Mr. Neff's friend in Fortaleza is quoted as saying
“Yellow fever here is picking up and doing nicely!”

We have been advised by the Crown Agents for the Colonies
in London that they have received no reports of yellow fever in
Sierra Leone or Nigeria during the current year. They know, however,
Doctor Carter
November 17, 1922
2
of four cases on the Gold Coast, reported respectively on
January 13, February 17, July 22, and September 26, and one
case at Gambia, reported on October 7. We had previously
heard from the British Consulate in New York of a reported
death from yellow fever at Christiansborg, Gold Coast, on
September 21.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Wickliffe Rose. Doctor Henry R. Carter
2121 California Street, N.W.
Washington, D. C.
